an8.77:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an8.77:1.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an8.77:2.1.eng: “Reverends, these eight individuals are found in the world.

an8.77:2.3.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.77:2.3.eng: First, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.77:2.4.eng: They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.77:2.5.pli: Tassa uṭṭhahato, ghaṭato, vāyamato lābhāya lābho nuppajjati.
an8.77:2.5.eng: But material things don’t come to them.

an8.77:2.6.pli: So tena alābhena socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an8.77:2.6.eng: And so they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion because they don’t get those material things.

an8.77:2.7.pli: Ayaṃ vuccatāvuso, ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, uṭṭhahati, ghaṭati, vāyamati lābhāya, na ca lābhī, socī ca paridevī ca, cuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.77:2.7.eng: This is called a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. But when they do not acquire material things, they sorrow and lament. They’ve fallen from the true teaching.

an8.77:3.4.pli: So tena lābhena majjati pamajjati pamādamāpajjati.

an8.78:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi …pe…

an8.78:1.2.pli: chahāvuso, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.78:1.2.eng: “Reverends, a mendicant with six qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.78:1.4.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.78:1.4.eng: A mendicant is quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.78:1.5.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.78:1.6.eng: They examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.78:1.7.eng: Understanding the meaning and the teaching, they practice in line with the teaching.

an8.78:1.8.pli: kalyāṇavāco ca hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo, poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an8.78:1.8.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.

an8.78:1.9.pli: sandassako ca hoti samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.78:1.9.eng: They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.78:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, āvuso, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.78:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these six qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.78:2.1.pli: Pañcahāvuso, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.78:2.1.eng: A mendicant with five qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.78:2.3.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu na heva kho khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.78:2.3.eng: A mendicant is not quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.78:2.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.78:2.5.eng: They examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.78:2.6.eng: Understanding the meaning and the teaching, they practice in line with the teaching.

an8.78:2.7.eng: They’re a good speaker. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.

an8.78:2.8.eng: They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.78:2.9.pli: Imehi kho, āvuso, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.78:2.9.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.78:3.1.pli: Catūhāvuso, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, nālaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.78:3.1.eng: A mendicant with four qualities is good enough for themselves but not for others.

an8.78:3.3.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;

an8.78:3.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.78:3.8.eng: They don’t educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.79:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
an8.79:1.1.eng: “These eight things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an8.79:1.3.pli: Kammārāmatā, bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu aguttadvāratā, bhojane amattaññutā, saṃsaggārāmatā, papañcārāmatā—
an8.79:1.3.eng: They relish work, talk, sleep, and company. They don’t guard the sense doors and they eat too much. They relish closeness and proliferation.

an8.79:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno parihānāya saṃvattanti.
an8.79:1.4.eng: These eight things lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an8.79:2.1.pli: Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattanti.
an8.79:2.1.eng: These eight things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an8.79:2.3.pli: Na kammārāmatā, na bhassārāmatā, na niddārāmatā, na saṅgaṇikārāmatā, indriyesu guttadvāratā, bhojane mattaññutā, asaṃsaggārāmatā, nippapañcārāmatā—
an8.79:2.3.eng: They don’t relish work, talk, sleep and company. They guard the sense doors, and they don’t eat too much. They don’t relish closeness and proliferation.

an8.79:2.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha dhammā sekhassa bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an8.79:2.4.eng: These eight things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.”

an8.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā uttaro mahisavatthusmiṃ viharati saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ.
an8.8:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Uttara was staying on the Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in the Mahisa region near Dhavajālikā.

an8.8:1.2.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā uttaro bhikkhū āmantesi:

an8.8:1.3.pli: “sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
an8.8:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, it’s good for a mendicant to check their own failings from time to time.

an8.8:1.4.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
an8.8:1.4.eng: It’s good for a mendicant to check the failings of others from time to time.

an8.8:1.5.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
an8.8:1.5.eng: It’s good for a mendicant to check their own successes from time to time.

an8.8:1.6.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ parasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hotī”ti.
an8.8:1.6.eng: It’s good for a mendicant to check the successes of others from time to time.”

an8.8:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vessavaṇo mahārājā uttarāya disāya dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ gacchati kenacideva karaṇīyena.
an8.8:2.1.eng: Now at that time the great king Vessavaṇa was on his way from the north to the south on some business.

an8.8:2.2.pli: Assosi kho vessavaṇo mahārājā āyasmato uttarassa mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desentassa:
an8.8:2.2.eng: He heard Venerable Uttara teaching this to the mendicants on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain.

an8.8:2.3.pli: “sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.

an8.8:2.4.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.

an8.8:2.5.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.

an8.8:2.6.pli: Sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ parasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā hotī”ti.

an8.8:3.1.pli: Atha kho vessavaṇo mahārājā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ antarahito devesu tāvatiṃsesu pāturahosi.
an8.8:3.1.eng: Then Vessavaṇa vanished from Saṅkheyyaka Mountain and appeared among the gods of the thirty-three, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm.

an8.8:3.2.pli: Atha kho vessavaṇo mahārājā yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
an8.8:3.2.eng: Then he went up to Sakka, lord of gods, and said to him:

an8.8:3.3.eng: “Please good fellow, you should know this.

an8.8:3.4.pli: Eso āyasmā uttaro mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ deseti:
an8.8:3.4.eng: Venerable Uttara is teaching the mendicants on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in this way:

an8.8:3.5.pli: ‘sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
an8.8:3.5.eng: ‘It’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings. …

an8.8:4.1.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ devesu tāvatiṃsesu antarahito mahisavatthusmiṃ saṅkheyyake pabbate vaṭajālikāyaṃ āyasmato uttarassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
an8.8:4.1.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sakka vanished from the gods of the thirty-three and reappeared on Saṅkheyyaka Mountain in front of Venerable Uttara.

an8.8:4.2.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yenāyasmā uttaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ uttaraṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo āyasmantaṃ uttaraṃ etadavoca:
an8.8:4.2.eng: Then Sakka went up to Venerable Uttara, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

an8.8:5.1.pli: “Saccaṃ kira, bhante, āyasmā uttaro bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desesi:
an8.8:5.1.eng: “Is it really true, sir, that you teach the mendicants in this way:

an8.8:5.2.pli: ‘sādhāvuso, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti,
an8.8:5.2.eng: ‘It’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings …

an8.8:5.7.pli: “Kiṃ panidaṃ, bhante, āyasmato uttarassa sakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, udāhu tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti?
an8.8:5.7.eng: “Sir, did this teaching come to you from your own inspiration, or was it spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

an8.8:5.8.eng: “Well then, lord of gods, I shall give you a simile.

an8.8:5.9.pli: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
an8.8:5.9.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

an8.8:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, devānaminda, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahādhaññarāsi.
an8.8:6.1.eng: Suppose there was a large heap of grain not far from a town or village.

an8.8:6.2.eng: And a large crowd were to take away grain

an8.8:6.3.eng: with carrying poles, baskets, hip sacks, or their cupped hands.

an8.8:6.4.pli: Yo nu kho, devānaminda, taṃ mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ puccheyya:
an8.8:6.4.eng: If someone were to go to that crowd and ask them

an8.8:6.5.pli: ‘kuto imaṃ dhaññaṃ āharathā’ti, kathaṃ byākaramāno nu kho, devānaminda, so mahājanakāyo sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti?
an8.8:6.5.eng: where they got the grain from, how should that crowd rightly reply?”

an8.8:6.6.pli: “‘Amumhā mahādhaññarāsimhā āharāmā’ti kho, bhante, so mahājanakāyo sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti.
an8.8:6.6.eng: “Sir, they should reply that they took it from the large heap of grain.”

an8.8:6.7.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho, devānaminda, yaṃ kiñci subhāsitaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
an8.8:6.7.eng: “In the same way, lord of gods, whatever is well spoken is spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an8.8:6.8.pli: Tato upādāyupādāya mayaṃ caññe ca bhaṇāmā”ti.
an8.8:6.8.eng: Both myself and others rely completely on that when we speak.”

an8.8:7.2.eng: How well this was said by Venerable Uttara!

an8.8:7.3.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñci subhāsitaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
an8.8:7.3.eng: ‘Whatever is well spoken is spoken by the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an8.8:7.4.eng: Both myself and others rely completely on that when we speak.’

an8.8:7.5.pli: Ekamidaṃ, bhante uttara, samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate acirapakkante devadatte.
an8.8:7.5.eng: At one time, Honorable Uttara, the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.

an8.8:7.6.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā devadattaṃ ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
an8.8:7.6.eng: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:

an8.8:8.1.pli: ‘Sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attavipattiṃ paccavekkhitā hoti.
an8.8:8.1.eng: ‘Mendicants, it’s good for a mendicant from time to time to check their own failings …

an8.8:8.2.pli: Sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ paravipattiṃ …pe…

an8.8:8.5.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, asaddhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
an8.8:8.5.eng: Overcome and overwhelmed by eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.

an8.8:8.7.pli: Lābhena hi, bhikkhave, abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho;

an8.8:8.14.pli: pāpamittatāya, bhikkhave, abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
an8.8:8.14.eng: bad friendship, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.

an8.8:8.15.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi asaddhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
an8.8:8.15.eng: Overcome and overwhelmed by these eight things that oppose the true teaching, Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable.

an8.8:9.1.pli: Sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya vihareyya;
an8.8:9.1.eng: It’s good for a mendicant, whenever they encounter it, to overcome gain …

an8.8:10.1.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthavasaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya vihareyya;
an8.8:10.1.eng: What advantage does a mendicant gain by overcoming these eight things?

an8.8:11.1.pli: Yaṃ hissa, bhikkhave, uppannaṃ lābhaṃ anabhibhuyya viharato uppajjeyyuṃ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya viharato evaṃsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
an8.8:11.1.eng: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without overcoming these eight things do not arise when they have overcome them.

an8.8:11.8.pli: uppannaṃ pāpamittataṃ anabhibhuyya viharato uppajjeyyuṃ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, uppannaṃ pāpamittataṃ abhibhuyya viharato evaṃsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.

an8.8:11.9.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthavasaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ lābhaṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya vihareyya;
an8.8:11.9.eng: This is the advantage that a mendicant gains by overcoming these eight things.

an8.8:12.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an8.8:12.2.eng: “Whenever we encounter it, we will overcome gain …

an8.8:13.1.pli: Ettāvatā, bhante uttara, manussesu catasso parisā—
an8.8:13.1.eng: Honorable Uttara, this exposition of the teaching is not established anywhere in the four assemblies—

an8.8:13.4.pli: Uggaṇhatu, bhante, āyasmā uttaro imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ.
an8.8:13.4.eng: Sir, learn this exposition of the teaching!

an8.8:13.5.pli: Pariyāpuṇātu, bhante, āyasmā uttaro imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ.
an8.8:13.5.eng: Memorize this exposition of the teaching!

an8.8:13.6.pli: Dhāretu, bhante, āyasmā uttaro imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ.
an8.8:13.6.eng: Remember this exposition of the teaching!

an8.8:13.7.eng: Sir, this exposition of the teaching is beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”
